Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ultimately, any system that pays interest, needs to get the coins from somewhere. All the komodo pegged coins are 100%+ backed, so we cant just create it out of thin air. the 5% liquidation gains come from the accounts that have less than 10% equity left

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so the risk takers are subsidizing the ones that didnt take as much risk. in exchange they had proportionally more stablecoins they could use in turn to liquidate other accounts, or spend, or trade

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: many have complained that KMD lacked liquidity. once we have EURK, there is a much much larger amount of liquidity that can be tapped into. and it doesnt require selling on the open market

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: does a coin having the ability to convert itself into stable form on demand, have extra value?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in my mind it does, especially as the friction of charging interest is eliminated. i think in some cultures, anything that is charging interest is not allowed. and generally speaking having to pay interest is not a good thing and leads to all sorts of bad outcomes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so in the spirit of increasing freedom and interest, the komodo pegged and backed stablecoins are not charging interest

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: Maybe another way to think about it, is that it is a way to margin trade KMD. When you do that typically you need to borrow coins and pay interest. I have not been able to find any coins that you can borrow at 5% a year.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: since it is a useful feature and unique to my knowledge, i am sure effective marketing can be done for it.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it wont compete against the other crypto deposits that pay interest so it can be loaned out at higher rates

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and it might be much more useful to existing community members, but the way i see it, that just makes it easier to get new people into the community

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: tl:dr it is not a copycat system that tries to compete against ETH/DAI

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: We just need fiat on/off ramps to accept the pegged coin, well exchanges too.

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: a fiat pegged Smart chain with nSPV Antara modules will make all my crypto dreams come true

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: The best systems in place without users or a place to spend it at, is just as good as the worst system. Let's not forget that utility is the driver of all things.

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
imo nSPV Antara modules in the browser will drive massive adoption
as it makes crypto more accessible to front end devs 
and, as there are no gas fees, users need not fear using it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: already have a couple of EUR gateways in discussions

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so you would be able to send the EURK to the gateway and do a SEPA transfer from there

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and nSPV support for pegs and gateways chains are definitely needed and in development

Author: hastrup#8742
Content: it is not exactly the notary nodes, but rather composed of 13 msig operators. how would that work? is it automatet so they "only run a note" or do they need to copy pasta private key every time a loan is pay out? are they going to be paid?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
> but rather composed of 13 msig operators
as jl said, they are going to be longtime commuity members (some of them past notary nodes)

>  how would that work?
all of them are registered as msig signers when the smartchain is launched

>  is it automatet so they "only run a note" or do they need to copy pasta private key every time a loan is pay out?
it is automated, they only run a node. all the required code to do the transfers and locks is present in the komodo repo

Author: hastrup#8742
Content: thats make sense.  is there a plan for if some of them go rouge?

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: They would need 6 others to all do the same im guessing?

Author: criptobear#6402
Content: So if hypothetically speaking I put 1000€ in KMD (let's say = 2000KMD) then I borrow EURK 700 and I use them, in the meantime KMD goes up 5x I put back 700 EURK and i get back 2000kmd valued at 5000€ but if it goes down I will get liquidated when a threshold gets reached and I get liquidated by another user who buys my locked KMD for a price determined how? Where is the documentation?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: <https://docs.komodoplatform.com/basic-docs/antara/antara-api/pegs.html>

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
> I get liquidated by another user who buys my locked KMD for a price determined how?
price determined by the decentralized trustless oracle that is created on chain as a part of the mining process
prices cc implements it

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: <https://medium.com/@jameslee777/decentralized-trustless-oracles-dto-by-piggybacking-on-timestamp-consensus-rules-2adce34d67b6>

Author: joe2x4#5987
Content: I think I understand the mechanism of the kmd-stable coin. Are there any special steps when initially creating a stable coin chain in order to get the market moving? Let's say I create k-pickle. It tracks the price of pickles. I lock $1000 kmd and receive $800 k-pickle. I'm the only person with K-pickle. Kmd looses value and the account is at less then 80% backed. At this point, are my kmd indefinitely locked as there is no market and I got k-pickled?

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: @joe2x4  somebody could liquidate the kmd backing the kpickle at that point

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: If no one else had kpickle it would be stuck

Author: joe2x4#5987
Content: So in a thin market, it will just be locked until someone liquidates it. Also maybe this situation won't happen as there is a cost associated with chain creation, as why would anyone want to spend money for a stable coin they really can't use.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: probably not a good idea to run a stablechain on a whim, it takes commitment and also need a federated set of signers that can be collectively trusted not to collude. in case one goes rogue, or more likely unresponsive, then the funds can be moved to a new msig address based on a new set of signers, but this process is not implemented yet

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the nightmare scenario is if the backing drops so fast in a day, that the liquidation cant keep up and it never rises above that price. in that case, the stablecoin value should be prorated to whatever the amount backing it is. though with tether, it doesnt seem to matter so much the amount that is backing it

Author: joe2x4#5987
Content: In regards to artik123 comments about the 5% kmd rewards going to the signers, to me it doesn't seem to far a stretch that eventually we will see competing stable coin chains. EURK+ pays 1% back and signers keep 4% type of thing.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: nothing prevents this. our reference version wont be doing that, but any coin can be used for backing (bitcoin protocol) and if using KMD, the msig signers are free to use it however they want, including rebates

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is a full matrix of possible stablecoins as the backing coin is independent from what is being pegged

Author: artik123#2884
Content: I've changed my mind. jl you have very compelling arguments. Better to keep it the way it is for now

Author: hastrup#8742
Content: in case one goes rogue, or more likely unresponsive, then the funds can be moved to a new msig address based on a new set of signers.......thx for the answer.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: This might be of interest xdaichain.com ,  some crucial differences but is a close analogue .  Pretty good idea they have ,  stablecoin based version of Eth .  Their format may be a good candidate for the dual daemon approach that jl777 wrote about a little while back.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Where the one coin is a stablecoin and the other chain which gets burned on to is the dual daemon ( could be Eth , cosmos , NEO whatever clone ).  This makes any crypto tech stack  priced in fiat .
